subject: Home & DIY
title: Chinese Furniture and the Art of Joinery
description: A quick win: understand Chinese Furniture and the Art of Joinery.

hook.text: Ming Dynasty furniture uses no nails, no screws, no glue. Pieces hold together through interlocking joints alone.

buildup.text: Chinese craftsmen developed hundreds of joint types, each designed for specific stress patterns and wood movements.

discovery.text: The joints expand and contract with humidity, keeping furniture tight across seasons without cracking or loosening.

twist.text: Some joints are deliberately designed to be disassembled for moving. Flat-pack furniture is a 600-year-old Chinese idea.

climax.text: Ming chairs sell for millions at auction. Their clean lines directly inspired Danish modern design in the 1950s.

punchline.text: No nails. No glue. Still standing after 600 years.

quiz.question: How do Ming Dynasty furniture joints adapt to seasonal changes?
options: They expand and contract with humidity without loosening
They use flexible bamboo pegs that bend
They're sealed with lacquer to prevent movement
